Fervent Fans of ‘Moby-Dick’ Flock to This Massachusetts Town to Read the Book Cover to Cover
Once the whaling capital of the world, New Bedford remembers Herman Melville’s literary masterpiece with an annual reading marathon
On a recent cold winter’s afternoon, the faithful gathered at the high altar of literary devotion to hear the gospel preached by a pious soul. Congregants filled the seats of the tabernacle and ringed the loft like sailors at the taffrail of a ship leaving harbor on a long voyage. Many held their “bible” in prayerful hands to follow the impassioned preacher as he intoned the famous first line of that potent prose:
“Call me Ishmael.”
Thus began Massachusetts Poet Laureate Regie Gibson as he read the first chapter from what is regarded by many to be America’s greatest novel, Moby-Dick; or, the Whale by Herman Melville. Erupting in applause and shouts of joy, the overflow audience at the New Bedford Whaling Museum then settled in for a 25-hour-long reading by more than 300 people of the masterpiece, which tells the tale of a 19th-century whaling expedition wrought with obsession, tragedy, derangement and revenge.
For 30 years, the Moby-Dick Marathon has been an annual tradition in New Bedford. Once the whaling capital of the world, the Massachusetts port is where Melville departed on a voyage to the South Seas in 1841. This year, more than 3,100 devotees from around the country and across the seas attended the service, which began on January 3 (the 185th anniversary of Melville’s whaling trip), and nearly 250 remained overnight.
“It’s one of our oldest, greatest American novels,” Gibson says. “Connecting to the history and imagery that Melville gives us is astonishing. As a poet, reading it out loud you really see what poetic techniques are being used. There’s repetition; there is alliteration; there are subtle hints of rhyme; there is all of this beautiful stuff that he is doing to make it … a cavalcade of sound that brings you in like the sea does.”
The story of Moby-Dick
For the uninitiated, this tale of self-destruction is told through the perspective of Ishmael, who seeks to escape the “damp, drizzly November in my soul” by taking an ocean voyage. Along the way, he befriends harpooneer Queequeg, a Polynesian native who wants to experience the curious culture of American and European sailors. They sign on to the whale ship Pequod, captained by the fanatical Ahab, who lost his leg to a mighty white whale known as Moby-Dick. They set forth on their doomed voyage from New Bedford and sail to the Pacific Ocean, where an obsessed Ahab leads the hunt, only to lose his life, ship and most of his crew to the leviathan.
The allegorical nature of the story makes it even more profound. When Melville published Moby-Dick in 1851, the United States was on a cataclysmic course toward Civil War. The writer embellished his book with imagery evoking the coming conflict and the blind attitudes of a society bent on an all-consuming conflagration.
“It was an experimental novel,” says Nathaniel Philbrick, author of Why Read Moby-Dick? and other award-winning books on history, including In the Heart of the Sea, about the 1819 ship sunk by a whale that Melville built his story around. “It’s one of those timeless works of literature that is written at such a high level. It’s about a society on the verge of a catastrophe. Somehow, Melville works that into a story of a whaling voyage.”
Quick fact: "The city that lit the world"
- New Bedford, Massachusetts, was once the wealthiest city per capita in North America. Its wealth came from exporting whale oil, used in lamps and candles in the days before electricity, in the 19th century.
Born in 1819, Melville came from a wealthy background, though his father squandered that fortune. To survive, he worked a series of jobs, as a schoolteacher, shopkeeper and merchant mariner. He then tried his hand at whaling.
Melville took up writing after his experiences on the South Seas, which were recounted in the romanticized adventure-travel book Typee (1849), along with several novels and books of poetry. Sadly, Moby-Dick did not achieve the initial acclaim Melville hoped for, and his fame began to fade.
Melville died in 1891 believing his sacred tome had fallen on deaf ears. Amazingly, Moby-Dick sold fewer than 3,200 copies in his lifetime. Critics found the story “absurd,” and readers weren’t interested in a novel style that diverged so sharply from the simple adventure books they were used to reading. Scholars rediscovered his writings during a 1919 centennial celebration marking his birth. Moby-Dick gained popularity when Nobel laureate and author William Faulkner stated, “I wish I had written that.” He equated it to a Greek tragedy and viewed it as the pinnacle of American writing.
Philbrick echoed those sentiments when he wrote in 2011: “For me, Moby-Dick is more than the greatest American novel ever written; it is a metaphysical survival manual—the best guidebook there is for a literate man or woman facing an impenetrable unknown: the future of civilization in this storm-tossed 21st century.”
Whaling history runs deep in New Bedford
Masterwork aside, Melville is revered in New Bedford for his deferential descriptions of the city. When Moby-Dick resurfaced as a classic in the 20th century, it helped the community reclaim its early grandeur. For a time, New Bedford was the wealthiest community in the country because of the vast fortunes made from the whaling industry. At its peak in the mid-19th century, the port was known as “the city that lit the world,” because much of the oil from harvested whales was used in lamps. In 1857, 329 whaling ships valued at $12 million in today’s money called New Bedford home.
Melville’s ode to New Bedford in the novel remains a source of community pride:
The town itself is perhaps the dearest place to live in, in all New England. … Nowhere in all America will you find more patrician-like houses, parks and gardens more opulent, than in New Bedford. … All these brave houses and flowery gardens came from the Atlantic, Pacific, and Indian oceans. One and all, they were harpooned and dragged up hither from the bottom of the sea.
Today, the city’s waterfront is filled with links to its whaling past and Melville’s novel, retaining much of its former glory in the form of cobblestone streets, elegant mansions and buildings, statues and memorials, and more. A brewery is even named after the great whale, and countless stores and cafés honor the literary masterpiece. But as pervasive as the whale is about town, what keeps the seaport vibrant today is the more humble sea scallop. New Bedford is now the hub for the world’s largest sea scallop fishery, and host to an annual scallop festival with a shucking contest and other events.
The shining temple of the city is the New Bedford Whaling Museum, where the Moby-Dick Marathon begins in an exhibit hall featuring the Lagoda, a large model of a whaling ship that sailed from New Bedford more than 150 years ago. While a series of readers lyrically delivers the humor and honesty of friendship on a shipboard journey, as well as the ferocity of a duel to the death on the high seas, listeners are enchanted by the presence of the half-scale replica of the three-masted bark that braved a trip around Cape Horn and plied the seas in search of bounty.
Opened in 1915 on historic Johnny Cake Hill, the museum houses more than 750,000 whaling-industry artifacts, including 3,000 pieces of scrimshaw (whale bones and teeth hand-etched by whalers) and 2,500 logbooks from whaling ships. Both collections are the largest of their kind in the world. The museum complex covers an entire city block and includes 20 exhibit galleries, featuring five complete whale skeletons as well as artwork by major American artists who lived or worked in the New Bedford area. Collections of art and furniture from the 19th century serve as a reminder of the immense wealth generated by the whaling industry.
The whaling museum attracts visitors year-round, but it becomes a holy site during the Moby-Dick Marathon, held traditionally on the first weekend in January. Events are staged over three days and include a dinner and lecture with Melville experts, a “Stump the Scholars” session and discussions about art, whaling and New Bedford. Hot coffee flows through the night, and gift bags are distributed to those who make it through all 25 hours of the marathon.
“We had our largest crowd in history this year with 3,193 people,” says Annelise Conway, the museum’s chief engagement officer. “Some are Melville die-hards. Some are literary tourists who come for the bucket-list experience.”
If the whaling museum is the high altar, then the Seamen’s Bethel is the chapel. The marathon moves briefly to this location just across the street for the chapters on a portentous sermon about the biblical prophet Jonah, who was swallowed by a whale. Visitors cram into this simple chantry, where the walls are lined with cenotaphs dedicated to New Bedford sailors who lost their lives on faraway seas.
Melville and his brother Gansevoort visited the bethel, built in 1832 as a spiritual haven for mariners, just prior to departing New Bedford to “go a-whaling” on the ship Acushnet. Little has changed at the old mission, except for the pulpit, which the New Bedford Port Society restyled in 1961 to resemble the prow of a ship depicted in the 1956 movie Moby Dick, starring Gregory Peck and Richard Basehart.
Within the next 15 months, the city will install a statue honoring Herman Melville on the grounds of the Seamen’s Bethel. Standing over seven feet tall, the bronze sculpture with a grey patina will feature the author in a sea swell framed by three large whale ribs.
A treasured tradition
For Don Kreis of Concord, New Hampshire, the Moby-Dick Marathon has become an annual pilgrimage of sorts. He read at last year’s event and decided to do so again this year with his 24-year-old daughter, Rose Keller, who lives in Augusta, Maine. Both are “Moby-Dick fanatics, like people who go to Grateful Dead concerts,” he says. He read the novel to her when she was a baby, and both call it their favorite book.
For the 2026 marathon, they selected the 3 a.m. time slot, with father going first, followed by his daughter. Despite the hour, the museum gallery where the marathon concludes was packed with reverential souls, all listening intently.
When Kreis stepped to the podium, he began reading “Chapter 81, The Pequod Meets the Virgin.” This is when the New Bedford ship encounters a Dutch vessel that has not yet harvested a whale, known as a “virgin” to the salty whalemen. The two ships then launch their smaller boats of harpooneers to chase the same sperm whale.
“When you sign up to read, you don’t get to pick the section—just the time,” Kreis says. “As I started reading, I realized it was Rose’s favorite chapter. I started reading it and then she took over after five minutes. We call this our ‘Moby-Dick Miracle.’”
Both father and daughter are planning to read at the 2027 Moby-Dick Marathon.
Perhaps it’s preaching to the choir, but the entire weekend is devoted to celebrating the one true religion as passed down by a prophet and literary genius who understood the spiritual needs of successive generations of readers.
“We know that Moby-Dick is relevant,” Conway says. “We know people still want to read that book and understand it and really dissect it.”

Read Love Letters From Royals and Romantics Across 500 Years of British History
A new exhibition at Britain’s National Archives features a letter to Elizabeth I, Jane Austen’s will and a plea to free Oscar Wilde from prison
Declarations of love and loyalty spanning 500 years of history are now on display in a new exhibition at Britain’s National Archives, open just in time for Valentine’s Day.
Titled “Love Letters,” the show features correspondence between a wide-ranging group of letter-writers. Monarchs, spies, celebrities and everyday Britons bare their bleeding hearts with expressions of anguish, hope, longing and joy. These tender messages are now available for the public to read, for free, through April 12 in Kew, London.
“The National Archives holds a surprising array of expressions of love—some criminalized, unconsummated or tragically cut short—found across 500 years of state records,” Vicky Iglikowski-Broad, the principal records specialist at the National Archives Council, says in a statement. “This exhibition takes visitors on a journey of emotional connection and reflection, revealing how love connects all kinds of people and takes many forms, often in the most unexpected places.”
One of the most iconic documents on display is the final letter written to Elizabeth I by her suitor, Robert Dudley, Earl of Leicester, just before his death in 1588. Elizabeth never married, and the letter from Dudley was found at her bedside when she died 15 years later. The missive had been marked with the words, “his last lettar” [sic].
Showcasing expressions of love across social classes is a major theme of the exhibition. An 1851 petition written by an unemployed, 71-year-old weaver named Daniel Rush urges officials not to separate him from his wife by placing them in different workhouses. The document is displayed next to the Instrument of Abdication of Edward VIII, who relinquished the throne in 1936 so that he could marry Wallis Simpson, an American woman who had previously divorced.
“There is a lot of connection in these two items even though on the surface they seem very different,” Iglikowski-Broad tells the Associated Press’ Jill Lawless. “In common they have just this human feeling of love … that the sacrifice is actually worth it for love.”
Sacrifice and secrecy defined the relationship between John Cairncross—a British civil servant who was later identified as a spy who leaked information to the Soviets—and Gloria Barraclough, a woman who likely never knew that her lover led a double life.
“Writing to you seems to have some magical effect on me,” Cairncross expressed in a letter in 1944. “Your letters have a lightness, vivacity and joie de vivre … a fresh voice from an exquisite past.”
Barraclough’s son, Tom Brass, found letters between Cairncross and his mother tucked into her copy of his autobiography. But before he could ask her about them, she died.
“My mother came from a category of women whose lives were deemed to be of little or no interest,” Brass tells the Guardian’s Amelia Hill. “But these love letters … show that before she was a wife and mother, she was loved by a spy for her vibrancy and intelligence.”
Not every artifact in the exhibition swells with romantic love. Familial love, calls for justice and even expressions of outrage can be found on many pages on display. Jane Austen’s will, handwritten in 1817, bequeaths all her possessions to her beloved sister, Cassandra.
Quick fact: Jane Austen’s letters
Though the English novelist likely wrote thousands of letters during her lifetime, only around 161 are known to survive.Meanwhile, a large collection of letters written by members of the public defend Ira Aldridge, a playwright and early Black Shakespearean actor, who faced racism throughout his career. In another letter, Lord Alfred Douglas—himself the recipient of one of the most famous love letters ever written, Oscar Wilde’s De Profundis—begs Queen Victoria to pardon Wilde, who had been imprisoned for his homosexuality.
“Love Letters” is on display at Britain’s National Archives in London through April 12, 2026.

articles.content:
Snow Drought Hits the Western United States, Worrying Experts About the Region’s Water Supply
Snow melt from the mountains provides up to 75 percent of the West’s yearly water
While winter weather blanketed much of the United States in snow last week, mountains in the western part of the country are sparser than usual. The amount of compressed snow, or snowpack, in some spots has hit historical lows, culminating in a snow drought.
Colorado’s snowpack is “the lowest on record for this point in the season,” Peter Goble, the assistant state climatologist of Colorado, tells Evan Bush at NBC News. Utah is in a similar situation, per the outlet, as well as certain places in California, says Daniel Swain, a climate scientist at the University of California Agriculture and Natural Resources, in an online presentation.
“At least one ground-based monitoring station in every major western watershed recorded the lowest [amount of water stored in the snowpack] in at least 20 years on January 26,” according to a statement from the NASA Earth Observatory.
That’s not just bad news for winter sports enthusiasts. Snowpack is a natural reservoir of fresh water, which slowly melts and provides up to 75 percent of the West’s annual water supply. The diminished snowmelt will likely add to the megadrought currently burdening the Colorado River, and it could exacerbate regional wildfires come summer.
The snow drought seems to partially be a consequence of unusually toasty temperatures. “Washington, Oregon, California and many Western states had their warmest December ever on record,” Philip Mote, a climate scientist at Oregon State University, tells NBC News. “And so, the torrential rains that we had with the atmospheric river and the flooding and damage from too much water—none of that stayed in the mountains.”
Instead, the Pacific Northwest’s rainstorm that took place from December 1 to December 15 melted much of the snow, and “paradoxically left the region’s water supplies worse off in its wake,” writes Alejandro N. Flores, a hydrologist at Boise State University, for the Conversation.
Quick fact: What’s an atmospheric river?
Much like a traditional river, these are long, thin areas in the atmosphere that move water vapor. They transport the vapor out of the tropics and dump it elsewhere as rain or snow.
And more recently, much of the West has been experiencing an unusually long dry spell, meaning the snowpack isn’t getting replenished.
Scientists can’t pinpoint the exact reasons for the region’s recent weather conditions, since it’s difficult to attribute the snow drought to climate change alone, reports Jim Robbins at the New York Times. Still, computer simulations that forecast weather suggest that the events aren’t merely a one-off.
“The predictions are we will get less snow because the precipitation base will be rain rather than snow, and the line at which snow accumulates will keep creeping up,” says McKenzie Skiles, a snow hydrologist at the University of Utah, to the outlet.
The snow drought comes at an already bleak time for the Colorado River basin, which supplies water to 40 million people and has been experiencing a historic drought since 2000. Western states have been negotiating management of the river’s dwindling resources for years, and the snow drought makes the situation even more pressing. More than half of the West’s runoff, water that flows into bodies of water, comes from snowmelt, according to a 2017 study.
Policymakers from seven states met last Friday to reach a new water-sharing agreement, but for now, they remain at an impasse. “In the short run, having a low snowpack year may raise the urgency of coming to some of those agreements,” Goble tells NBC News.
The conditions have also affected the region’s ski industry. For instance, the company Vail Resorts said that only 11 percent of its terrain in the Rocky Mountains was open in December, and that snowfall then and during the previous month was 60 percent below average, reports the New York Times.
February and March might bring more snow, although that may not make up for the current deficit. “In places such as the Pacific Northwest and the Colorado River Basin that are already dry, snow drought may turn into or exacerbate traditional drought,” per the statement.
Additionally, more arid conditions could exacerbate wildfire risk by creating an abundance of dried plant matter, which is the primary fuel for fires. Climate change-enhanced drying has roughly doubled the area of forest fires in the West from 1984 to 2015, according to a 2016 study.
Experts are now working on ways to better predict snow drought and its consequences—work that will become more important as the events become more common, Flores writes for the Conversation.

articles.content:
A New App Can Match Footprints to the Dinosaurs That Made Them
Using artificial intelligence, DinoTracker can accurately classify dinosaur tracks around 90 percent of the time
New inventions can come from unexpected places. After reading a book on the history of dinosaurs to his son, physicist Gregor Hartmann realized that the artificial intelligence methods he worked on in photon science might have an application in paleontology. He reached out to the book’s author, paleontologist Steve Brusatte, with the idea, and DinoTracker was born. The new model uses A.I. to classify fossilized tracks to different dinosaur species.
Hartmann’s team published the model’s findings in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences last week, and the DinoTracker app is now available on GitHub.
Until now, most paleontologists have identified dinosaur tracks in fossils manually or based on previous classifications, which can sometimes lead to biases or misclassifications, Hartmann tells the Guardian’s Nicola Davis.
“You never find a footprint and alongside [it] the dinosaur that had made this footprint,” Hartmann says. “So, no offense to palaeontologists and such, but most likely some of these labels are wrong.”
Unlike previous models, DinoTracker was trained on almost 2,000 unlabeled dinosaur footprints, which it sorted into classifications based on eight key characteristics. These included spread of toes, amount of ground contact and heel position. After over a year of training the neural network, the model aligned with human classifications around 90 percent of the time.
“I wish there was an app like this when I first started studying dinosaur tracks,” Brusatte, who co-authored the report in PNAS, says to Rachael Funnell at IFL Science. “It really is challenging to understand the variation among tracks that were made by different dinosaurs and preserved in different environments, and this app now makes everything more objective.”
Because the model’s only input is the track itself, human experts still oversee and confirm the classification based on additional context of age and location.
“This app certainly isn’t the end of the story when it comes to puzzling over the mysteries of dinosaur footprints,” Paige dePolo, the report’s co-author, writes in the Conversation. “It’s a useful research resource for figuring out what tracks any footprint is most similar to in terms of shape, and what features are driving that similarity.”
DinoTracker also supported paleontologists’ previous observations that some three-toed dinosaur tracks are remarkably similar to bird tracks. This confirmation from an unbiased, computational source is significant, Brusatte tells IFLScience
“Our dinosaur footprint A.I. model shows that some of these mysterious, controversial three-toed Triassic tracks really do resemble those of birds,” he says. “The humans studying them were correct. It wasn't just wishful thinking, or that they were seeing a bird shape in the tracks in the same way somebody imagines the face of Jesus on a slice of toast.”
This raises the hypothesis that birds or bird ancestors originated nearly 60 million years before scientists previously thought. But tracks are not a perfect representation of the creature that made them, dePolo writes in the Conversation.
Fun fact: Record-setting site
- Bolivia's Torotoro National Park is home to 16,600 exposed three-toed dinosaur footprints—the most ever found in one location.
“Dinosaur footprints are not perfect snapshots of the feet that made them," she writes. "They reflect the shape of the foot, how the dinosaur was moving, and how soft or hard the ground was at the time.”
Jens Lallensack, a geoscientist at Humboldt University of Berlin, who has also used A.I. to help identify dinosaur tracks but was not involved in the study, tells the Guardian that the birdlike tracks do not directly reflect the shape of the foot and “are not evidence for an early appearance of birds.”
The scholars have made the model publicly available as an app on GitHub for both expert and amateur dinosaur lovers.
“I think A.I. has a bright future in paleontology,” Brusatte tells IFLScience. “It's not that A.I. will become some all-knowing god that can identify every single fragment of dinosaur bone or tell us exactly where to find every fossil in the rocks. But what excites me most is that A.I. can become a new type of paleontologist, one that compiles and observes and filters through and classifies data and does so in a way that is free from the usual human biases.”

articles.content:
Megalodons Went Extinct Millions of Years Ago. The Prehistoric Predator Could Become Maryland’s Official State Shark
Teeth belonging to the fearsome creatures have been discovered throughout the state. Now, they’re up for consideration by the state legislature
For nearly 20 million years, megalodons prowled the world’s oceans. The massive creatures, which could grow up to 80 feet long and weighed about 94 tons, used their large teeth and strong jaws to subdue whatever prey they encountered—from whales and large fish to other sharks.
The fearsome predators went extinct roughly 3.6 million years ago. But they’re still making waves today: Maryland is now considering whether to make the megalodon its official state shark, reports WMAR-2 News’ Megan Knight.
The effort is spearheaded by Stephen Godfrey, curator of paleontology at the Calvert Marine Museum in southern Maryland, and his colleague John Nance, who serves as the museum’s paleontology collections manager.
They say the discovery of megalodon teeth throughout the state makes the prehistoric giant worthy of the designation. The creatures’ fossilized remains have turned up in numerous Maryland counties, and the Calvert Marine Museum has several on display.
Did you know? Calvert Cliffs
- One of the most popular sites for finding megalodon teeth is the Calvert Cliffs area of southern Maryland.
- Prehistoric fossils often emerge as the waves and the wind erode the cliffs.
Paleontologists have also discovered evidence of a possible megalodon attack: a pair of 15-million-year-old fractured whale backbones. The teeth of several other prehistoric shark species have also been found in Maryland, which scientists think was once a feeding and calving ground for numerous extinct species.
“Turns out no state has a state shark, so we’re hoping Maryland is the first,” Godfrey tells WMAR-2 News. “To me, this is such an iconic animal. I think it’s time for megalodon to take center stage as the first shark designated as a state shark.”
Godfrey and Nance helped write two bills—one for each chamber of the state legislature—which were introduced for first reading on January 14, per WBOC’s Sean Curtis. If the legislation passes, megalodon would become Maryland’s state shark on October 1, 2026. The gargantuan beasts would then join other state symbols, such as the Baltimore oriole, the white oak and the black-eyed susan.
“The megalodon, although extinct, lived in this area for millions of years and is a reminder of the important role modern and prehistoric sharks have played in shaping past and present ecosystems,” according to House Bill 97.
Though Maryland might become the first to adopt a shark, states have honored prehistoric creatures in other ways. Minnesota, for instance, recently named the giant beaver its state fossil. About the size of a small bear, the creatures roamed the area that is now the Twin Cities more than 10,000 years ago. Other official state symbols include the mammoth (Nebraska), Stegosaurus (Colorado), the mastodon (Michigan) and the ichthyosaur (Nevada).
